narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q8: We werent really TAUGHT much in this class - it was more Michael's thoughts on various subjects, and then the presentations of the guest speakers...I don't know how you could go about making it different, but at times it bordered on pontification and that was challenging to sit through.

The readings were helpful. However, writing reactions to readings is always a wasted exercise. We're at grad school because we want to be here. "Busy work" assignments just to prove that we're actually doing the reading is a bit demeaning.Also, I have a major problem with the system of participation points, which is basically the TA making a check mark next to our name whenever we say something in class or ask a question. This is absurd. So, the people with loud mouths who say unintelligible things get more points than people who are intrinsically more reserved yet might be getting more out of the class than the first group? Also, in a class of 30 people, where there's usually only 5-10 minutes reserved for questions, the environment isn't very conducive to this process.
7b/c - Liz was an amazing TA. Very organized and always willing to talk about the class.
I came into the class with low expectations, but really ended up learning a lot about a part of environmentalism that I'm not very familiar with
It took me a while to realize what was at the heart of the class. When I did, I realized it is probably one of the most valuable classes offered at FES.

This course has been refreshing, rewarding, and a true training for us future natural resource practitioners when we go out into the real world of environmental policymaking.It was exciting to hear directly from on-the-ground practitioners how they organized and implemented their environmental campaigns; especially when some of us had been exposed to their communications and outreach strategies.

The chance to hear from outside practitioners about what they learned, as well as the chance to engage with the tactics of current campaigns/finding out what they were working on right now. I enjoyed my final project as well.
Providing dinner for us is a major plus. It allows people with busy schedules to take the class and not worry about when/if they are going to eat dinner.
The group project forcing us to think about how we would organize a capaign.
How helpful Michael is in connecting us to people with our interests and bringing in good speakers.

The readings synched up so well with the speakers; reading across disciplinary areas and social issues provided new frameworks through which to view campaign issues closer to my heart; the historical insight from Bury the Chains was fantastic (I've used it in conversation ever since); I learned a ton about how to think creatively around framing an issue; the discussion was good.
the speakers, and the professor's connections with people. He truly helps you out with your own project (which is a fun one!)
The guest speakers!
We could learnt the real story from real campaigners.

Practical nature of the course - directly relevant to what people want to do after graduating. Michael Northrop's direct experience of the field and his network of campaigners is an essential part of what makes the course work.
Water Wars lecture
dinner&how practical it was

Learning from and exchanging with practitioners in the field; exploring a campaign or topic of personal interest and practicing campaign modeling with a group. Meals were unbelievable. Michael is a flexible and supportive instructor who really tries to cultivate a unique and applicable class.
The final project (the ability to study a particular campaign in depth)
-learn 'real world' practical skills, issues-meet interesting people who are accomplished in their field
It was inspiring to hear from speakers who have led successful campaigns and made a difference.
Great speakers every week.Dinner every week.The Director of RBF is the instructor !! What more can you ask for?
The lectures, both by the professor and the guest speakers.
The methodology based on expositions from persons that participated in campaigns was the best. It allows students to understand the campaigning issues from real experience testimonies.
Guest speakers, Michael Northrop's insight, and the final paper.

- Prof. Michael Northrop is AMAZING!- He has designed a very special course with real-life examples of some of the best environmnetal campaigns ever implemented in the United States and around the world.- Extraordinary selection of invited guest speakers- Night course schedule as it allows to combine it with other day courses.- Liz's organization and food selections (connecting our meal selections with our social and environmental values)I believe the most pragmatic course is the one that provides authentic tools to our professional development. I have already benefited from the knowledge gained throughout the courses presentations and discussions, through ideas that I am already applying to my real-life work and environmental campaigns.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Timing could be better -- most classes ran over, and time limits (i.e. student presentations were supposed to be 5 mins) were NOT respected or enforced, which was quite challenging.
I don't feel there was enough in-depth analysis. We listened to speakers, but it would have been good to discuss some of the details more in depth as a class.
guest lectures were sometimes too long

Michael, I feel very strongly that you should have a closed laptop rule during classes. The School of Management has that rule so that students actually pay attention and contribute meaningfully to conversation during classes, and I think that this class is ripe for good conversation, but that people gchatting or playing online is interfering. Try it next year - I think you'd be surprised at how the quality of student participation increases.
Going over the time limit!
LONG class!

A bit more structure in terms of drawing together lessons from the different speakers during the semester.Also, readings at times seemed pretty random (i.e. good, but a lot of reading and not always particularly related to the speaker that week). Some more selection in terms of assigning book sections rather then whole books would be good.
The readings - out of date and too vague.

It would be great for speakers to have been aware of the collective class background before they came to speak (perhaps a paragraph on our work and campaign experiences) so that they could tailor their lectures to us as a class.
More discussion, fewer speakers.
-a little juggling of speakers - some were AWESOME, others a little lacking in enthusiasm or charisma...
More involvement from the professor/more inclusion of his experiences rather than of those he knows.
I don't believe this course need any improvement.
Integrating readings into open discussion.

- Just a general recommendation to start the course with a one-day or half-day workshop on environmental campaign design framework to help contextualize the different campaigns strategies andtactics taught throughout the course.- More time for final class presentations (15 minutes per presentation plus 5 minutes for questions)- Inviting guest speakers to talk about successful local and community campaigns from groups that have very little budgets, such as environmental justice groups, small-scale campaigns in the New Haven/Yale community

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Available and helpful.
Both Michael and Liz made it very clear that they were available to discuss the class. Michael was able to provide good advice regarding the individual end-of-semester assignment.
Both were very available and responsive.

Liz was very responsive to email queries and did a great job of getting people fed. Michael was also super responsive to emails - it was very flattering to hear one's comments referred to in class, and to know your reflections were being taken so much to heart. Very refreshing.
very available and I loved that he responded to emails right away, and very cordially.
Michael Northrop was really invested in the class and very available to help
Fantastic support from Prof Northrop and Liz. Just a bit more guidance earlier on in terms of expectations for paper length etc.
Instructor was very helpful with final paper - putting us in touch with people etc.
Excellent. Liz and Michael were both flexible and available, working hard to make sure we had the connections and support we needed for our project.
Both were easy to access and provided assistance.
both were excellent - made themselves available, accessible, very responsive. Michael was awesome!
Northrup was always interested in hearing from students. He was also available for questions or to discuss papers.
Michael was very accessible and approachable.
Both were very open to chatting and email.
Michael and Liz were always available to provide quality advice and recommendations.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: As someone interested in policy, it was good to gain a better understanding of how campaigns work.

I'm interested in persuasion - in what it takes to convince the public that a given environmental issue matters, and matters enough that they should take action. Although my actual degree is far from the content of campaigns (I'm a forester), there is a lot to be learned about how to brand and bind an initiative in order to create public buy in. I think I learned a lot about creating change, a skill I think everyone at FES is seeking.

This is an incredibly important course for anyone looking to work in environmental policy after graduation (i.e. most of FES). Taking this course means that people looking to be involved in or run campaigns right after graduation don't have to reinvent the wheel in putting one together but can learn strategies from what has happened before.

I hope to work in program management with community groups and nonprofits in the future and this exposed us to some of the nation's best and brightest campaigners. It is an applied or at least apply-able class in contrast to many skills or theory-based classes.
Provided input on a unique skill set that anyone in the environmental field can use.

It is really helpful, since I'm interested in environmental justice, and a lot of advances in EJ have relied on successful environmental campaigns. It was great to see these campaigns broken down in a classroom setting - I didn't expect to have the opportunity to study campaigns at FES, and it ended up being really helpful.
I'm interested in environmental communication. Understanding the role of campaigns is critical to the engagement of any environmental cause, especially if trying to rally support around it.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted experience with other campaigns.
There aren't enough classes on environmental communications and campaigning. F&ES students graduate with no communications skills whatsoever.
To gain a better understanding of what makes a successful campaign and what to expect if the target of a campaign.

It sounded interesting, it was very different than the other courses I had taken, it included dinner (otherwise the time of night would have prevented me from enrolling), and I needed a slightly lighter/more fun course that would allow to focus most of my intellectual energies on my thesis writing.
I want to know how to make the policy in the US.

From the very first lecture (Mat Jacobsen) this course reminded me about why I'm excited to be in this field. Mat's unparalleled passion for wild spaces echoes the passion I hope to bring to my work and showed by example how each of us as environmental leaders must learn to share our campaigns and causes to a wide audience if we are to form effective policy. While not every speaker appealed to me as strongly, I enjoyed hearing about each person's campaign and quest from Dick Amper to Becky Tarbotton to Tom Kruz.
to learn about real campaigns, what makes them successful, what kind of people run them, issues and challenges.
Understanding how to engage the public is essential for whatever career you choose.
I wanted to learn about campaigns because I didn't know how it worked. It was great to learn how PR and campaigns influence policy decisions today.
To learn more about how campaigns work, and what makes them successful.

Because we do not need to re-invent the wheel...we need to take time to reflect on the lessons learned from enviromental campaigns. This course provides the space to do exactly just that...REFLECT!As Susan Clark states in her Foundations to Natural Resource Policy book:people place a higher value on action  the expectation for professionals in conventional settings is to act; not to think or reflect. The single most important element in learning to reflect more effectively and that many professionals lack, is having time to reflect

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: I was surprised how out-dated several of the campaigns were, both in terms of tactics and how long ago they took place.
Yes
See 18
For sure. It exceeded them.
Yes and more!
Yes, very perfectly.
Yes.
Yes
YES!
Yes
The course went beyond my expectations.
Yes
For me, this course was an elective. My interest was based mainly in understanding how environmental policy can be created to reflect the public will.
Yes...and more!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Given the overwhelmingly positive feedback of previous students in the course, I thought it would be much better. It wasn't bad but it wasn't the best course I've ever taken.
Yes

I do have a better understanding of campaigns, although I feel without actual experience, my understanding plateaued midway through the semester. Perhaps instead of the end of semester paper, the course could be taught as a practicum, with the class running a short-term local campaign.
yes
Yes absolutely.
Somewhat. I think I had expected to get to know more people in organizations, but maybe that's my own fault for not speaking enough with the speakers.
YES and more!
Yes.
Yes
YES!
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes

More than I expected. It took time, but over the 14 weeks the importance of the content sank in. We were hearing about real cases of campaigns gone well, as well as how opposing forces organize coalitions for opposing campaigns. The structure of organized parties and ideas emerged from this class, as did the tactics used in advancing political agendas. Invaluable stuff for anyone in this field.

Yes...and more!From each campaign, there are so many lessons to be learned. Quotes and tactics from our presenters that I will treasure include: The power of strong coalitions and coalition-building. Keep good relationships with allies, makes it harder for them to sell you out Choose a strategic target but stay on top of the larger context Be hard on the issues, but soft on the people Take time in developing an inspiring story for the campaignFraming is not trivial Create a unifying demand set, but keep it simple with 3 or 4 demands. Protest with an alternative proposal at hand that benefits the common interest. Provide a vision that is pragmatic. Be ready to negotiate, but know your limits. Make the radical reasonable Make it personalreputations and brands mean everything. Tarnish brand image (a company always knows what it brand is worth). In looking into the future companies rule government, so the checkout stand is the new voting booth Never underestimate the power of students. Cultivate in-house intelligence. Ask what science demands, take what you have leverage to get. Be flexible and always look for the next campaign opportunity.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group assignment about a New Haven-hypothetical campaign was fine, but ill timed--easily could have been scheduled earlier in the semester/planned for more meaningfully and not thrown in at the end of the semester amongst all the other final deliverables. Also, the 5 minute presentations turned into 15-20 minutes a group which I think does a great disservice to teaching people how to present within a given time-limit and got downright boring.
As a group, we had to design a campaign and discuss how it would be implemented. This was a very worthwhile excercise in forcing us to think through the details.
For presentations - it was fine, I am kind of neutral on what that added to the class. It was not detrimental, I think it was just okay.
The group work I felt was unnecessary.
great group, great bouncing ideas off of each other.
Very nice. I studied very fresh thinkingway.
it was a 5 min exercise don't sweat it

I enjoyed practicing building a campaign. It might be interesting as a before/after exercise or an activity where we break into groups at the beginning of the semester and formulate the campaign strategies and tactics throughout the semester based on what we draw from each week's speaker.
Group work was minimal, but good for sparking discussion and sharing ideas.
IT WAS fun to work in small groups for the 'mock campaigns' at yale, good input from others.
The team presentation was fun, and a great learning experience.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I think this is really a campaigns 101, so think twice if you've had experience working on campaigns as it can get repetitive.
Get started on your interviews early!
This is a great class, and not to be missed. Definitely worth the credits and terrific for anyone moving towards work in the nonprofit/persuasion sphere...
Pick a campaigntopic that you're really interested in. Also, participate in class as much as possible.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in policy. Take full advantage of the opportunities to talk to interesting people afforded by the final paper.
take advantage of the speakers

Enjoy! Such a cool opportunity to explore a campaign that intrigues or fascinates you, make connections in an area of your choice and learn about some amazing people, places, and efforts!Thanks Michael! Thanks Liz!
TAKE IT. Michael is awesome and the course is great - good exposure to issues and campaigns of the past and ones currently ongoing. reading was super interesting.

I highly recommend this class. The guest speakers are generally great, and you just can't learn about running environmental campaigns in a book. My only advice is that it helps to know of a campaign you want to write about before you take the class or early on in the semester.
The class has excellent speakers who are well accomplished and over achievers in their field of expertise. Have fun interacting with them.
I would recommend it, and would recommend doing the 3 credit option! I wish I'd had the time in my schedule to do it.
Take the 3-credit option and start to think about campaigning from the first day of class.
Think not about the details of each campaign, but about the broad implications and general groupings of tactics from the very beginning. This is an illuminating topic.

DO NOT MISS THE OPPORTUNITY TO BE A PART OF THIS IMPORTANT COURSE! You will use the knowledge gain in your future endeavors.As mentioned previously, this course has been refreshing, rewarding, and a true training for us future natural resource practitioners when we go out into the real world of environmental policymaking.
